commercial aircraft

Safest Mode Of Transportion

Commercial air travel is the safest form of intercity transportation in the United States. Every day U.S. airlines transport more than 2.4 million passengers and more than 58,000 tons of cargo. Safety is our number one priority. PCC Aero and our member alliances work together with the Department of Transportation, Federal Aviation Administration, National Transportation Safety Board, Department of Homeland Security, Transportation Security Administration, Customs and Border Protection, aircraft manufacturers, labor and others to provide a safe and efficient travel experience. As a result, the U.S. airline industry is experiencing the safest period in aviation history.

creator of markets

Commercial aviation helps drive more than 10 million American jobs and 5 cents of every dollar of U.S. GDP. Our member alliances contribute at the local, state, national and global levels, helping to transporting people and goods around the world safely, efficiently and economically. The industry supports and creates new markets at home and abroad, as communities across the world rely on access to air transportation for economic growth and stability.

improved fuel efficiency

Between 1978 and 2018, U.S. airlines improved fuel efficiency by over 130%, which has resulted in nearly 5 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide savings. Our partners have a strong record of environmental responsibility. Today, our engine components are quieter, cleaner and use less fuel than ever. Carriers continue to invest in new aircraft and engines, winglets, alternative fuels and operational procedures – both in-flight and on the ground – among many other initiatives to create cleaner, greener skies for us all.

Driver Of Jobs

Our member alliance partners provide wide-ranging job opportunities from engineering to customer services. For every 100 airline jobs, approximately 300 are supported outside of the airline industry both directly and indirectly, including aviation-related government agency positions, such as air traffic controllers employed by the FAA, and research and development positions that enable advancements in all facets of airline operations.
